fields.standfirst: New independent Co-op director reveals fierce board-level resistance to plans for sweeping reforms to the stricken mutual
fields.body:
A huge canvas hangs on the brilliant white walls in the kitchen of Lord Myners' Belgravia home bearing the words: "Heaven is a place where nothing ever happens."

If it is a sign that the silver-haired Labour peer – who has a fascination with theology and describes himself as an old man in a hurry – is looking for his own heaven, the events of the past week suggest he might have quite a long wait.

Since last week's leak to the Observer about a £6.6m pay deal for the Co-op's new boss Euan Sutherland – which prompted Sutherland to walk out – Myners' battle to convince the board of the country's biggest mutual that it needs radical change have been blown into the open. A deep rift at the heart of a group that employs 90,000 in chains of supermarkets, funeral homes and pharmacies has been exposed.

The departure of Sutherland on Tuesday, after just 10 months in the job, is a "tragedy", according to Myners, who was parachuted into the Co-op just before Christmas as senior independent director to devise a new way to run an organisation mired in controversy. A £1.5bn hole in the Co-op bank, now filled after the backing of US hedge funds, ripped apart the group's reputation. Its image was then further tarnished with last November's allegations that the former chairman of the bank Paul Flowers bought illegal drugs and hired rent boys.

Myners is no stranger to boardroom drama: he sat on the board of NatWest when it was taken over by Royal Bank of Scotland (he lost his job) and he chaired Marks & Spencer when it fended off a hostile bid by Sir Philip Green.

But at the Co-op he swiftly discovered that the appetite for change was far from universal. He describes an "absolute wall of resistance": within days of arriving, Myners says he was told by one director that he controlled 25% of the votes at the annual meeting – enough to block any proposals for change. Another individual told him his proposals would be blocked, regardless of what he came up with.

As his black labrador, Ruan, settles into his basket in the airy kitchen of his home, Myners chooses his words about last week's leak carefully: "It looks like a malicious leak to damage [Sutherland] and destabilise my review."

Yesterday he published his review several weeks earlier than he had intended after some members of the board started to backtrack on promises made late on Monday night to adopt his ideas in principle in a last-ditch attempt to stop Sutherland leaving.

The 65-year-old, who made his fortune at the fund management firm Gartmore, had learned about Sutherland's resignation via text message at 6am on Monday morning. That led to an emergency meeting that night where Myners outlined his proposals to scrap the existing board and replace it with one akin to a plc. In the end it was to no avail after the BBC reported Sutherland's resignation on Tuesday, making it impossible for to stay on.

Myners, who was chairman of Guardian Media Group until the 2008 banking crisis, when he was elevated to the Lords to become City minister, is suggesting the views of members are heard through a new national council of members.

But there are already indications that some in the Co-operative movement see the proposals as so radical that they constitute a takeover of the mutual, whose board currently comprises 20 members elected from the Co-operative movement with Myners in the newly created role of independent director.

The board is part of the "democracy" of the Co-op although Myners is doubtful about the real level of democracy for the eight million owner-members of the group. The board itself needs its decisions to be ratified at the annual meeting by the regional boards. It is a system, he says, that operates on block votes, rather than one member one vote.

"The Co-op is controlled by less than 100 people – ordinary members have no votes at all," said Myners. The ethos, he said, was that the management was meant to be "on tap but not on top" - reflecting the views of the members. "There's been self-serving delusion that the current model has the members in control when for the last decade or so the executive had run circles around the board." His model may yet be too radical for those who want to see "co-operators", as they are known, with a seat at the boardroom table.

But Myners insisted he has not mishandled the situation by being too outspoken about his need for change, particularly at a meeting on 1 March with members of the regional boards. "You have to confront people with uncomfortable truths," he said. "I don't pull my punches. I'm not looking for a fight [but] there was no point pretending everything was all right," he said.

Surprisingly to those who know Myners as an outspoken critic of boardroom pay – he is a former chair of the Low Pay Commission – he is sanguine about the pay deals for Sutherland and the other seven members of his executive team. Sutherland's £6.6m was made up of £1.5m salary for each of 2013 and 2014, £1m to buy him out of deals at B&Q's owner, Kingfisher, and another £1.5m each year in "retentional deals".

Myners, describing himself as "very passionate about reward", and astute enough to take on his role for a £1-a-year fee, said: "This is one of those positions where you hold your nose. Your principles can't exist in an ivory tower."

The retention deals, which doubled the pay for the management team to £12m, were agreed in July when the bank was on the brink and the management team needed to be reassured. "They [the board] were fighting a fire and they needed to be sure the firemen weren't going to leave," said Myners.

It is not clear what evidence there was that the newly assembled team was about to walk away, although Myners insists that Sutherland was not going to accept the payout. "The leaking of the [pay] report reflected the decisions taken nine months ago and I have every confidence that come the [annual] meeting it was Euan's intention to say he did not want these payments," Myners said.

Richard Pennycook, who was hired as finance director, is now stepping up temporarily as chief executive. Myners said: "He is ideally placed at the moment when continuing bank support is important." The debts of £1.2bn were "higher than any sensible person would judge appropriate. "Yet still around the board there are people wishing to pursue narrowly focused agendas around happy chickens and other such matters.

"I want chickens to be happy but we don't need to spend as much time as we do on these issues," he said.

"The financial situation is challenging. The attitude of the banks is supportive but the banks clearly expect the co-op take action to fix itself," said Myners.

Perhaps even more surprisingly, Myners insists that he does not want to become the next chairman of the Co-op and may not even stand for election at the annual meeting. "We'll see," he said. "If the Co-op rejects my report I couldn't stay. It would be a nonsense."

He said the recruitment of a chief executive should be put on hold until his reforms are passed, possibly as soon as the annual report. He also insists that not only does he not want to not chair the Co-op, he does not want to hold that position in any other organisation. "I'm driven by a wish to have a meaningful life and to try to make effective contributions on issues which matter ... This is too important to let the Co-op fail."

webTitle: Extent of Co-op shambles laid bare by Lord Myners

fields.bodyText: The shambolic state of the Co-operative Group was laid bare in a scathing verdict warning that the survival of Britain's biggest mutual organisation was at stake. The Co-op has been undermined by "reckless" dealmaking, "shocking" levels of debt and governance standards far worse than even the banks before the credit crunch, according to Lord Myners, the group's senior independent director who was charged with overhauling the boardroom. In an exclusive interview with the Guardian, the City grandee who was installed as a Labour minister at the height of the credit crisis said: "I have observed the bad governance of the banks, but this is on an altogether worse level. "The rate of deterioration has increased over the last half dozen years because of the recklessness of the strategy being pursued and supported by the board." He added that the entire retail, funeral home, pharmacy and farming conglomerate would deteriorate further unless it was radically reformed. Myners, also an ex-chairman of Marks & Spencer and Guardian Media Group, said the Co-op's reputation as a business run democratically by its members was a myth. He said the company's most senior managers were left to waste billions of pounds on disastrous corporate transactions because the directors drawn from the Co-op movement were not qualified to keep them in check. "Few of them have any serious business experience and many are drawing material financial benefits from their positions." Myners said the Co-op's elected directors – who include a plasterer, lecturer, tax official, nurse and farmer – had overseen "breathtakingly value-destructive" deals, including the takeover of the Somerfield supermarket chain and the Britannia building society. It was the Britannia deal that left the Co-op bank facing a £1.5bn financial black hole and resulted in the bank being taken over by US hedge funds. Myners, called in to review the group's governance in December, proposed far-reaching changes that he said would ensure it could stay true to the Co-op's democratic ideals and still be run on commercial lines. In a report rushed out – just days after the group's chief executive, Euan Sutherland, quit and branded the organisation "ungovernable" – Myners concluded that: • The group's "massive failure of governance" had "gravely damaged the organisation", letting its business decay and leaving it financially weak. • Its members, who supposedly own the business, have almost no say in what the board or managers decide. • Unless the governance is reformed "it will run out of capital to support its business". Myners said it was a tragedy that Sutherland had quit because the Co-op owed its survival through last year's bank crisis to him and his team. He said what he had uncovered at the Co-op was so serious that the group had no choice but to change. "What I think I have exposed is that the Co-op is not a democratic organisation and has a deeply flawed governance structure, and if it doesn't address these issues the pace of decline will simply increase. The reality is that the Co-op has been in decline for 60 years." The organisation had "the worst governance I have ever witnessed" and "shocking" levels of debt, some of which was hidden by complex property deals, he said. The group currently has debts of £1.2bn. "This is folly in the extreme. This really pains me." He said that the group, led by £1.2m-a-year chief executive Peter Marks until last year, had been obsessed with making large acquisitions instead of competing in the cut-throat world of grocery retailing, which is its main business. The crisis at the Co-op came to a head last week when Sutherland resigned, after just 10 months, when the Observer revealed his £3.6m pay package. Sutherland said that senior colleagues were determined to undermine him and he blamed them for a series of damaging leaks. Myners claimed Sutherland never intended to take the £2m of bonuses awarded on top of his £1.5m salary. The money was agreed before Myners became involved and, he said, should have been revealed earlier. Britain's biggest mutual company was plunged into chaos last May when a £1.5bn financial hole was revealed at its banking arm. The capital shortage had forced the Co-op to abandon its bid for more than 600 Lloyds bank branches and has led to US hedge funds owning most of the bank. The problems deepened in November when the bank's former chairman, Paul Flowers, was alleged to have bought class A drugs and used rent boys. Myners said the Co-op had lost almost all the customers it picked up when it bought Somerfield in 2008 for £1.6bn. He said taking over the Britannia had almost bankrupted the Co-op bank and the attempted Lloyds deal, codenamed Project Verde, was misconceived: "Somerfield was reckless. Britannia was reckless. Verde was reckless." Myners said he had worked four days a week for three months examining the group's "labyrinthine" structures and coming up with proposals. He will be paid £1 for his efforts. The Flowers affair triggered a string of inquiries into the turmoil at the group, whose ethics and democratic structure had been lauded as an alternative to the big bonuses and ruthless business practices of City-controlled companies. Myners said his proposals would make the group more democratic by involving its currently- ignored wider membership while making sure people with business experience were in charge of commercial decisions. He faces opposition from within the group's senior ranks who accused Sutherland of trying to scrap the values established by the Rochdale pioneers who founded the group in 1844. But Myners argued even his most entrenched opponents now realised the status quo could not stand. Myners said the group's directors had been paid hundreds of thousands of pounds in the last few years as the group was driven close to ruin. "It depresses me. It's a controlled anger," he said. He rejected claims he had alienated board members with his uncompromising verdict on their abilities and the Co-op's record. He called for the replacement of the group's 20-strong elected board with a smaller board of six or seven non-executive directors with business experience and two executives from the group. Members would be represented on a new National Membership Council to hold the board to the group's values and principles. Directors would be elected and reelected each year by all members, overhauling the current system which puts power in the hands of a few hundred activists.

webTitle: Cock-up after cock-up: the Co-op Group must change or perish | Nils Pratley

fields.bodyText: Adapt or die. Don't doubt the accuracy of Lord Myners' blunt message to members of Co-op Group. There are at least three reasons why the organisation is doomed to irrelevance, or worse, if it cannot recognise the size of the mess it is in. First, the Co-op's commercial record is appalling. Over 50 years, its share of the grocery market has fallen from a Tesco-like 30% to 5%. The past decade has seen cock-up follow cock-up. The Co-op overpaid for Somerfield in 2008 in pursuit of greater size and buying power but, in terms of market share, it finds itself back where it started. Meanwhile, the Co-op Bank is now 70% owned by outsiders after a £1.5bn capital hole appeared. Sir Christopher Kelly's postmortem on the saga is awaited, but it's obvious that the acquisition in 2009 of Britannia Building Society, with its over-sized book of souring commercial property loans, was the prime cause. Myners' verdict on the Somerfield and Britannia deals – "breathtakingly value-destructive" – is supported by the numbers. Second, the rebuke that the Co-op suffers from a "democratic deficit" will sting because it is true. Ordinary members of the Co-op do not even get an automatic right to vote at the annual meeting. Instead, a system of block-votes from regional committees survives. This is a version of democracy but it has not produced a main board of elected members with the nous to prevent calamities like the Britannia deal, or even the madcap attempt to buy 630 branches from Lloyds. As argued here more than once, it's safe to run an amateur golf club via elected committees and sub-committees but you're inviting trouble at a business with an annual turnover of £11bn, 2,800 shops and hard-nosed competitors such as Tesco, Sainsbury's and Asda. Myners' proposal would see the Co-op adopt a main board akin to a plc board – that is, with a majority of independent non-executive directors and two executive directors. Then a "national membership council," charged with policing co-operative values, would be created. Of course, big-name independent non-executives can also be dozy and incompetent – just look at Royal Bank of Scotland circa 2007 – but Co-op members should note that Nationwide Building Society and John Lewis recognise the need for external voices in the boardroom. Those organisations are prospering; theirs is failing. Third, the financial facts are serious. The society is about to announce a loss estimated at £2bn, it owes its banks £1.2bn at the last count and a mini price war has broken out in the supermarket sector. Throw in long-term pension liabilities and past sale and leaseback deals, and mainstream banks will not be queuing up to lend to an unreformed Co-op. The society would risk being slowly taken to the cleaners by its lenders. If losing control of the bank was painful, try being told to sell your successful funeral service. None of the above excuses the absurd spectacle of the Co-op's board agreeing to pay Euan Sutherland £3.6m in his first year as chief executive – on a guaranteed basis, for heaven's sake. The sum would have been princely even for a successful mid-ranking FTSE 100 company. Myners says Sutherland intended to waive the bonus element of his package. If so, the now-departed chief should have said so, instead of handing ammunition to his boardroom opponents. Indeed, his pay terms should have been published on the day they were agreed, which is how grown-up companies in the quoted sector behave. Naïvety all round. If Sutherland had been cuter, and thicker-skinned, he could still be in post. But the useful part of his departure is that the Co-op will now have to confront its troubles. Few top-tier chief executives would risk joining the Co-op until the governance debate is settled, so there is no point trying to hire a replacement until a vote on Myners' proposals, or any alternative reforms, has happened. So hurry up. Terrible timing Here's a rule of thumb for investing in leading retailers: when a share buy-back is announced, head for the hills – unless the company is called Next. Morrisons is the latest shopkeeper to demonstrate poor sense of its own worth and medium-term prospects. Amid this week's huge profit warning came news that the last piece of the £1bn buy-back programme, launched in 2011, had been completed. Last year's annual report shows how the bulk of the "equity retirement" scheme was deployed: £947m was spent acquiring 312m shares, which works out at about 300p a pop. Price now: 208p. Hindsight is wonderful, of course, but the retail sector has an inglorious record of terrible timing. Home Retail, the Argos and Homebase group, spent £150m buying 64m of its shares at 233p apiece in 2010-11, just before the price crashed to 80p and the dividend was cut. Marks & Spencer, in 2007-08, spent £592m at an average of 434p, just before a plunge to 200p and cut its dividend. Next is almost the only major retailer that gets it right. Two of chief executive Lord Wolfson's secrets are to do a little consistently – which in Next's case is ten consecutive years – and prefer special dividends if the share price outstrips growth in earnings per share Wolfson has a formula called "equivalent rate of return", to assist. Others seem to spend the money regardless of price and hope for the best. Naturally, Morrisons could point out that earnings per share were nevertheless boosted by its buy-back. Yes, but think how useful £1bn could be today. Buying 312m shares would cost £650m and Morrisons would still have £300m to super-charge its price cuts in the battle against discounters Aldi and Lidl. Too late now. 'Cynical opportunism' Boo, hiss, the Ruia brothers are following through on their threat to bid for the minority interest in Essar Energy, the Indian-based energy firm, at just 70p. "Our offer to minority shareholders represents a premium that is in line with precedent UK minority buyouts," said the statement from the Ruias' Essar Global fund, owner of a 78% stake. webTitle: Markets fear Russia has cut US treasury bill holding over Ukraine crisis

fields.bodyText: Financial markets were on high alert last night over the Ukraine crisis amid speculation that the Kremlin had pulled its vast US treasury bill holdings out of New York. News that more than $100bn had been shifted out of the US in the past week – at least three times more than at any time since the financial crisis – prompted fears that Russia is preparing for a western backlash in the form of sanctions and is moving its funds to safe havens beyond US influence. The bills were transferred out of the US central bank's deposit vaults last week, as the Obama administration increased the threat of sanctions in response to the growing crisis in east Ukraine. Last year the most moved in a week was $32bn. Analysts said that if the switch can be credited to Russia, it represents about 80% of the country's holdings in US Treasury bonds. The Russian central bank is likely to be behind the move, though wealthy Russian business figures are also expected to be concerned that Washington-imposed sanctions will freeze funds they have parked with the US central bank. Alexei Miller, the boss of energy firm Gazprom, and Igor Sechin, who runs oil company Rosneft, are likely to be among the many senior figures in Moscow adversely affected by any targeted sanctions imposed on Russia. The switch came to light after the US central bank reported that its weekly custody holdings of Treasury bonds – investments it keeps on behalf of outside investors – dropped $105bn for the week ending 12 March to $2.85tn from $2.96tn.

webTitle: Quiznos joins fast-food chain Sbarro in filing for bankruptcy

fields.standfirst: Both restaurants have lost ground to the growing boom of sandwich chains with a tilt towards custom, healthy options
fields.body:
Intense competition for the taste buds of time-pressed American consumers is hurting weaker, less competitive fast-food restaurants this week as sandwich chain Quiznos and pizza-and-pasta group Sbarro both filed for bankruptcy protection.

Neither filing was a surprise, preceded in the case of Quiznos by over three years of struggle with the company’s growing debt load, which weighed in at over $500m at the time of the filing on Friday morning. Sbarro, similarly, had filed for bankruptcy in 2011 and struggled with lower foot traffic and expensive real-estate leases until its second filing this week.

Both Quiznos and Sbarro, their heydays long past, have lost ground to the growing boom of sandwich and fast casual-food chains with strictly defined identities that tilt toward customizable dishes and healthy options: Connecticut-based Subway for fresh sandwiches, Chicago-based Potbelly Sandwich Works for nostalgic comfort food, Illinois-based Jimmy John’s for fast delivery, Chipotle Mexican Grill for inexpensive Mexican food from organically grown ingredients.

Yet while Subway, Chipotle and Potbelly thrive – Potbelly launched a successful initial public offering last year – Quiznos and Sbarro failed to keep up.

“They have both been struggling, lost their way, didn’t have a clear identity, and were not doing anything really substantive to contemporize and revitalize their position,” said Bob Goldin, an executive vice-president with food-industry consulting and research firm Technomic. “It’s a shakeout.

“They have a lot more competition [from other sandwich chains] than five years ago and more and more are coming,” Goldin said.

Quiznos’ 2,100 stores, nearly all of which are franchises owned and operated separately from the company itself, will continue to operate through the bankruptcy, the company said. CEO Stuart Mathis said Quiznos will use the bankruptcy to “reduce our debt, execute a comprehensive plan to further enhance the customer experience, elevate the profile of the brand, and help increase sales and profits for our franchise owners”.

Quiznos has long suffered frictions with its franchise owners, who have complained that the company imposes high costs on them for food and supplies. In a statement, the chain offered those franchise owners an olive branch, promising to reduce food costs, offer rebates and loans for restaurant improvements, increase advertising, provide incentives to new franchise owners, and improve technology in its restaurants.

The larger problem, aside from real estate and financial magic tricks, is that Quiznos and Sbarro had trouble drawing customers in recent years. Quiznos expanded too fast and Sbarro was doomed by its real estate strategy of placing its restaurants in shopping malls, where foot traffic has been declining for years as customers turn to online shopping. Their generic food, resistant to customization, also possibly turned off customers. Sbarro, for instance, never got past a reputation for last-ditch food with a limp, heat-lamp-heated look.

“Customers are looking for value because of high unemployment and the weak economic recovery,” said Mariola Borysiak, an associate director following the restaurant industry for Standard and Poor’s. “But they don’t want to compromise quality. The [chains] that offer high quality will be the winners.”

Although bankruptcy filings for restaurant chains are rare, according to Goldin, the most recent are not surprising to analysts. Quiznos and Sbarros struggled for years with their problems. While some may call that delaying the inevitable, “there’s always hope that they improve operations,” Borysiak said. “It’s probably better to be trying than just giving up and filing for chapter 11.”

While hope may spring eternal on that front, the scale of Quiznos problems could be daunting as competition intensifies from savvier rivals, Goldin said. “Bankuptcy will give them some breathing room, but they’ve fallen behind and can’t catch up.”

Quiznos and Sbarro are also part of a larger trend among lower-end food and retail chains. There has been an apparent contradiction in the economy as discounters and inexpensive food chains have gone under even though they should theoretically have been thriving as cheaper, sensible options in a struggling economy. Loehmann’s, an off-price clothing chain, liquidated and shut down its holdings in January, while JC Penney suffered a very public black eye with its failed strategy of “everyday low prices”. The restaurant industry, especially family dining like Red Lobster and Olive Garden, has suffered from the same perplexing loss of customers.

Borysiak attributed the struggles of lower-end chains to consumers who have become tight with money as economic conditions fail to improve. The national unemployment rate sits at 6.7% with fewer people participating in the labor force than any time since the recession of the late 1970s.

“Especially last year, the payroll tax increase, the government shutdown – all of these hurt consumer confidence,” Borysiak said. “The lower-end customer is still very cautious about discretionary spending.”

There are other chains that have been struggling, including Logan’s Roadhouse, which S&P recently downgraded to a B-rating with a negative outlook. The chain’s traffic has been declining for two years, Borysiak said.

The traditional path in the restaurant industry, however, is a long, slow struggle than an immediate collapse.

“There are a lot of chains that would be better off going bankrupt,” Goldin said. “They’ve been hanging in too long and not doing much.”

webTitle: Boohoo.com fashion website soars on stock market – ending day at £840m

fields.standfirst: Shares in the fast-growing online retailer started trading on the junior Aim at 50p but within 10 minutes had jumped 70% to 85p
fields.body:
The clamour to invest in fashion website Boohoo.com put a rocket under its share price when it floated on Friday, with the fast-growing fashion website finishing the day with a market value of £840m, nipping at the heels of established FTSE 250 retailers such as Ted Baker and Debenhams.

Shares in the Manchester-based company started trading on the junior Aim market at 50p but within 10 minutes had jumped 70% to 85p. They closed up 40% at 70p

The enthusiastic reaction from investors added to the paper wealth of the Kamani family who have already pocketed £240m from selling some of their majority stake in the business. The 44% stake retained by the family and other board members was worth £370m at close of trading.

Last week the retailer confirmed its IPO had raised £300m, with £50m of that retained for investment. The offer is understood to have been heavily oversubscribed.

The website, which targets 16-24-year-olds, was founded in 2006 by Mahmud Kamani and his business partner Carol Kane. The pair previously ran a successful business supplying high street rivals such as Primark and New Look and are joint chief executives of the listed company. Boohoo.com, which makes extensive use of social media, has been described as an online Primark, its mainstay being dresses selling for between £12 and £25.

Already shipping to 100 countries, Boohoo.com has impressive margins and made a profit before financial charges of £10m on sales of £92m in the 10 months to December. That compared with profits of just £3.5m a year ago.

But the runaway valuation has fuelled fears that the stock market is once again in the grip of dotcom fever. Shares in AO World, the domestic appliance website, soared as high as 44% during its first day of trading last month.

"As an online-only store, Boohoo.com is unconstrained by politics and a bricks and mortar based retail mindset," said Radcliffe Cole of internet specialists Tryzens. "It also has a loud and proud brand presence. This identity has been developed specifically with their target audience in mind: teenage girls."

webTitle: Co-op shoppers in Leigh 'shocked to see how it's gone downhill'

fields.standfirst: Customers at the forlorn Co-op store on Higher Folds council estate lament the business's shift away from its old values
fields.body:
For all the reputed geniality of its staff, the Co-op store in Leigh, Greater Manchester, is hardly an advertisement for the thrusting, brave new world the organisation imagines for itself.

Four days after Euan Sutherland walked out as the Co-operative Group's chief executive, more people seemed to be queuing for the cash machine outside than the shopping aisles within.

It is several years since the supermarket chain, which has more than 2,800 stores across the UK, surrendered Leigh town centre to the likes of Asda and Aldi. Today its one remaining outpost in the area is on the Higher Folds council estate, a forlorn, security-patrolled store at the end of a rank of similarly depressing shop fronts.

Deborah Beckles, 40, a student, had just called in for beer, bacon and sausages in preparation for her boyfriend's weekend visit, and was quick to lament the controversy engulfing the Co-op. Yes, she was well aware of Sutherland's departure, the group's £1.2bn debt, and the £3m-a-year pay deal the outgoing executive left behind.

"They're in a real mess, aren't they?" she said. "To be honest, I only come here now because it's the nearest shop, and if I want anything more than bits and bobs I go to Tesco.

"In the old days you felt you were part of it – part of the Co-operative movement, I suppose. But it's all changed. All they seem interested in is profits, like everyone else. My partner won't go in any more on ethical grounds. He thinks they've sold out."

Beckles is also uncomfortable about what she sees as the shift away from the Co-op's old values. "You used to feel it was being run by the people for the people. But nowadays it's just another supermarket, and more and more it just comes down to which is the cheapest."

Rita Hult, 83, once had a cleaning job at the nearby Labour club. "I'm shocked to see how it's all gone downhill," she said. "I used to have my milk delivered by the Co-op and I'd call into the store every day. Years ago there was a Co-op butcher's too, but that's now a hair salon."

Mary, a council employee, expressed disgust at the £6.6m two-year pay deal secured by Sutherland during his 10-month tenure at the Co-op. "Shame on him," she said. "I was brought up with the Co-op, and I just don't understand why they've been trying to make it more of a plc. What's wrong with it being cosy and cuddly like it always used to be?"

Staff at the store declined to speak.

The concerns in Leigh are echoed in the wider co-operative movement, where some fear that the Co-operative Group is becoming estranged from mutual values. Jim Lee, an active Co-op Group member for 25 years and the former secretary of the Scottish Co-operative party, said the group's democratic credentials were more mixed than the picture it painted to the public. "In some ways it's been a good story of development and democracy but in some ways it's become quite corporate and it doesn't seem to be that democratic.

"There are people who have had careers in the co-operative movement who are essentially corporate people. They don't have much time for the idea of mutualism. I've seen people asking hard questions at the AGM almost literally dragged down North Korean style. Officers from the Co-op Group would lean on their shoulder and say: 'It's been agreed you won't ask this question.' Maybe this has all been one massive wakeup call. Perhaps it's just too difficult to run something as big and complex as this in a purely democratic way."

Lee worries that the crisis at the group is bringing the wider co-operative movement, which includes independent retail co-ops and small businesses, down with it. "You can argue that the Co-op Group is destroying the brand. If you are a co-operative graphics business looking for work from clients, it can't be good for business. Potential clients may think: 'I've heard about these people. They can't run anything.' "

"There are people who have had careers in the co-operative movement who are essentially corporate people. They don't have much time for the idea of mutualism. I've seen people asking hard questions at the AGM almost literally dragged down North Korean style. Officers from the Co-op Group would lean on their shoulder and say: 'It's been agreed you won't ask this question.' Maybe this has all been one massive wakeup call. Perhaps it's just too difficult to run something as big and complex as this in a purely democratic way." Lee worries that the crisis at the group is bringing the wider co-operative movement, which includes independent retail co-ops and small businesses, down with it. "You can argue that the Co-op Group is destroying the brand. If you are a co-operative graphics business looking for work from clients, it can't be good for business. Potential clients may think: 'I've heard about these people. They can't run anything.' "
fields.headline: Co-op shoppers in Leigh 'shocked to see how it's gone downhill'
fields.trailText: Customers at the forlorn Co-op store on Higher Folds council estate lament the business's shift away from its old values

webTitle: FTSE 100 suffers worst weekly fall for nearly nine months

fields.standfirst: Investors nervous over Chinese slowdown, Ukraine tensions and Fed tapering
fields.body:
Leading shares suffered their largest weekly fall since June 2013, as investors reacted to a cocktail of concerns, from growing tensions in the Ukraine to worries about a Chinese slowdown to the prospect of the US Federal Reserve cutting back its economic stimulus again next week.

The FTSE 100 closed at 6527.89, down 25.89 points on the day and nearly 185 points or 2.75% on the week. That was its worst performance since it lost 3.05% in the week ending 21 June. It also marked a six day losing streak, the longest since November 2011, and a new five week low.

A host of poor Chinese figures, including trade data and retail sales, hit mining and emerging market shares, as did the worsening situation between Russia and Ukraine ahead of a disputed referendum in Crimea on Sunday, with the prospect of western sanctions against Vladimir Putin's government.

So Antofagasta fell 6p to 829.5p on the day or nearly 50p on the week, while Rio Tinto dropped 21.5p to 3140.5p and Glencore Xstrata lost 7.7p to 297p.

But with gold and silver back in vogue as safe havens, Mexican precious metals miner Fresnillo was Friday's biggest FTSE 100 climber, up 26p to 925.5p, while Randgold Resources rose 39p to £49.96.

Among those exposed to emerging markets Aberdeen Asset Management lost 11.7p to 365p on Friday, Prudential fell 28p to £13.46 while Coca Cola Hellenic Bottling, which gets the bulk of its profits from markets like Russia and Ukraine, dropped 36p to £14.33. Bank of Georgia was the biggest faller in the FTSE 250, down 172p to £21.93.

Back with the UK, supermarkets came under pressure after a profits warning from Morrisons on Thursday, which sent its shares down 12% and also hit rivals on fears of a price war as the major players tried to regain ground lost to discounters like Aldi and Lidl.

Morrisons recovered 2.8p or just over 1% on Friday while J Sainsbury jumped 8.7p to 313.6p as traders decided the falls were overdone. Tesco ended up 4.95p at 303.7p.

Elsewhere Royal Bank of Scotland dipped 1.1p to 299.5p following a downgrade by ratings agency Moody's late on Thursday.

BP slipped 1.25p to 477.25p despite the US lifting a ban on the company excluding it from new federal contracts, which was put in place following the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

Vodafone fell 2.25p to 222.15p amid reports it could be close to a deal to buy Spanish cable company Ono for around €7bn.

Privately owned Ono gave the go-ahead for a possible flotation on Thursday, but also kept the door open to a deal with Vodafone. Any move on Ono would be the latest attempt by Vodafone to build up its European businesses.

Meanwhile Aim-listed business telecoms group Daisy jumped 2.75p to 190.75p on talk that it could be a bid target for Liberty Global. Analysts at Liberum put a price target of 215p on the business, which values it at around £575m.

International Airlines Group lost 11.6p to 421.3p despite reaching a preliminary deal with 8000 ground staff at its Iberia subsidiary, while United Utilities dropped 7.5p to 786.5p after a downgrade from analysts at HSBC, who moved their recommendation from neutral to underweight in the wake of a recent Ofwat report on price controls. HSBC said it was time to take profits in United, given that uncertainties remained following the watchdog's announcement.

Lower down the market publishing group Future slumped 30% to 9.075p after warning profits would be significantly below expectations. Malcolm Morgan at Peel Hunt said:

The warning highlights, perhaps for the last time, that the transformation at Future should not be undertaken in the public markets. The improved trading seen in the Autumn then slowed towards Christmas and has not returned. We see little prospect for any pretax profit this year.

Finally, despite the market turmoil, a couple of retail flotations made impressive debuts. Discount chain Poundland priced its shares at 300p each and ended the week at 385p while online retailer Boohoo rose from its offer price of 50p to 70p on Friday, its first day of dealings.

But Pets at Home was less successful. It set a price of 245p a share but closed at 239.75p on Friday.

webTitle: North Sea gas leak report handed to prosecution authorities in Scotland

fields.standfirst: HSE says it is up to Scottish legal system to decide whether to prosecute Total after investigation into Elgin platform incident
fields.body:
A report into a gas release and safety scare in the North Sea platform operated by French oil company Total has been passed to the prosecution authorities in Scotland after a two-year investigation.

The Elgin platform spewed gas for nearly two months, forcing the crew to be evacuated and production halted.

The Health & Safety Executive (HSE), which investigated the accident with the Department of Energy and Climate Change (DECC), said it was now up to the Scottish legal system to decide what, if anything, happened next.

"We can confirm the HSE/DECC investigation reports into aspects of the well operations leading up the blowout have been presented to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service, who will now consider our recommendations and decide what action is to be taken," said an HSE spokesman.

The length of the investigation has been criticised in some quarters but the HSE said it was right to take as much time as was needed for such an important task.

There has been heightened awareness in recent days of North Sea safety with a judge-led inquiry reporting on Thursday into the crash of a Super Puma helicopter 11 miles off Peterhead.

Total was unable to comment but the company told a briefing of City analysts in 2012 that it did not expect to face prosecution over the gas leak, according to a note from RBC Capital Markets at the time.

Some environmental campaigners have said Total should not be allowed to "frack" for shale gas in Britain until it has been exonerated over the Elgin accident.

Lang Banks, Scotland director of environmental campaigners WWF, said it was "right and proper" that prosecutions be considered over the leak from Total's Elgin platform.

"While it was a relief that the Elgin leak was able to be stopped, the fact it happened at all and that a potent greenhouse gas was able to spew out for nearly two months was deeply concerning," he said.

"In the interests of tackling climate change and protecting the marine environment we urgently need to see a transition away from oil and gas toward pollution-free energy sources."

BP learned on Thursday that the Environmental Protection Agency in the US had agreed to lift a ban on the UK-based oil firm bidding for drilling contracts or licences – the ban was imposed following the Macondo blowout of April 2010 in which 11 workers died.

webTitle: FirstGroup set to run Great Western mainline until next decade

fields.standfirst: Labour takes issue with DfT's 'sweetheart deal' that will see First given further contract to run the service from September 2015
fields.body:
FirstGroup looks set to run the Great Western mainline until the next decade without facing a franchise competition – having earlier handed back its contract to avoid hundreds of millions of pounds in premium payments to the government.

The government is planning to award further rights to the service to the transport firm. Last September it sparked outrage by awarding first a six-month extension and then a two-year direct award to First for rail services west of London for an annual sum of £32m – a fraction of the £800m due under the terms of the original franchise.

The west coast debacle in 2012 saw franchising thrown into disarray, but the terms of direct awards and extensions since agreed by the Department for Transport have been questioned by Labour.

In a parliamentary answer the transport minister, Stephen Hammond, confirmed that from September 2015 the franchise was planned to be covered by a second direct award to First.

This may run until 2020 with a proposed extension.

The shadow transport secretary, Mary Creagh, said the deals would leave a £300m hole in the DfT's finances.

She said: "Ministers have now quietly announced another sweetheart deal with First Great Western Group, no doubt at rock-bottom prices, in stark contrast to their unwanted refranchising of the east coast line, run by a not-for-profit public operator which last year returned £191m to taxpayers."

A spokesman for First said: "The DfT has always stated that any decision on the future of the franchise would be based on delivering the best value for customers and taxpayers beyond September 2015.

Given the significant number of investment projects currently under way, and due to be completed over the next six years on the Great Western network, a directly awarded franchise covering the entire period of upgrades may create better overall value."

Only three firms are believed to have bid for the east coast line. On the Great Western line new trains will be introduced, along with electrification works and major station redevelopments over the next seven years.

webTitle: Lord Myners releases damning report into Co-op – as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Lord Myners’ recommendations for the Co-op
  • Russian stock markets fall to 2009 levels amid Ukraine tensions
  • FTSE 100 on track for biggest weekly fall since June
  • Boohoo.com surges 70% on stock market debut
fields.body:
3.09pm GMT

With this, we are closing the live blog for the day. You can follow the latest market moves on the Market forces blog, by my colleague Nick Fletcher. Many thanks for all your comments. We’ll be back on Monday. Have a great weekend.

Updated at 3.10pm GMT

2.59pm GMT

Incidentally, online fashion retailer Boohoo.com is trading as BOOB on Reuters. The shares jumped to 85p at the open and are now trading at 75p, still above the offer price of 70p.

2.51pm GMT

Summary

Here’s a summary of today’s events:

  • European stock markets have been jittery as the stand-off between Ukraine and Russia intensifies ahead of the referendum in Crimea on Sunday. The Russian stock market MICEX fell over 5% in early trading and is now down 0.6% at 1240.69. In London, the FTSE 100 index is 0.4% lower at 6528.93. Germany’s Dax has turned positive after earlier losses, up 0.1% at 9028.96. France’s CAC is 1% lower at 4207.06. Brent crude oil rose above $108 a barrel amid fears over Russian oil supplies.
  • Lord Myners has released a damning report on the Co-op, warning it will go bust unless it takes radical action
  • Boohoo.com jumped 70% on its stock market debut

Updated at 2.56pm GMT

2.37pm GMT

More reaction to Myners’ Co-op report.

2.32pm GMT

The boss of Britain’s financial watchdog has urged shareholders to get tough with banks if they want to see an end to huge bonus payouts.

Martin Wheatley, the chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority, said the competition for talent, which bank bosses cite as the reason they need to pay massive pay packages, was “self-perpetuating”, adding: “The trouble is if you just accept that you can never actually change this.”

Wheatley told the Evening Standard that investors

have started to grumble in quite a sotto voce way. They are not really getting in there with big sticks.

12.36pm GMT

Over in the US, producer prices fell by 0.1% in February following a 0.2% rise in January, offering little evidence of a pick-up in inflationary pressures – and giving the Fed leeway to keep interest rates near zero for many more months.

12.30pm GMT

On Monday 17 March at 6.45pm Lord Myners is doing a live webinar broadcast to discuss the progress he is making on the Co-op. If you want to participate, you can register and submit any questions here.

12.19pm GMT

Last year the Co-op faced the biggest crisis in its 150-year history with the need to recapitalise its Bank. The mutual’s crisis deepened this week when its chief executive Euan Sutherland walked out after just 10 months in the job, branding the organisation as “ungovernable”. His departure followed a report in the Observer about his £6.6m pay package for 2013 and 2014.

Updated at 12.40pm GMT

12.08pm GMT

Lord Myners' recommendations for the Co-op

Myners proposed a new board with an independent chair with no previous involvement with the group; six to seven independent non-executive directors; and two executive directors. This new board would chop the existing 20-strong elected board in half. He also proposed a national membership council of 100 individuals, including 20 employees, charged with ensuring the group adheres to co-operative values.

The recommendations will be put to the Co-op’s annual meeting in May.

Updated at 12.25pm GMT

12.03pm GMT

The Co-op report makes compelling reading. Castigating the mutual’s (lack of) governance, Lord Myners writes:

I am deeply troubled by the disdain and lack of respect for the executive team that I have witnessed from some members of the group board. There is a phrase frequently used in Co-operative group circles that the executive should be “on tap but not on top”. It is now clear to me that this is a widely held but deeply flawed representation of the reality in recent years. Elected directors have simply not been up to their task of holding the executive to account.

A second, quite fundamental concern is that this lack of effective governance exists in a situation where the Co-operative group’s core business is in food retailing, an economic sector with high competitive intensity.

The 20-strong Co-op group board does not include anyone from the executive team at present.

Updated at 12.10pm GMT

11.53am GMT

More from the Myners report on the Co-op:

The Co-operative group suffers from acute systemic weaknesses in its governance framework that over many years have gravely damaged the organisation. These failings include a series of costly strategic misjudgements that have undermined the group‟s competitive position and severely eroded its capital base.

The group board have collectively presided over losses of several billion pounds in the course of the last few years. Debt has reached levels that are no longer sustainable without the sale of treasured assets. Sale and leaseback transactions represent an expensive addiction the cost of which does not appear, even now, to be fully appreciated by the board.

Updated at 12.11pm GMT

11.52am GMT

You can read Lord Myners’ full report here.

11.51am GMT

Lord Myners releases damning review into Co-op

Former City minister and Labour peer Lord Myners is conducting a review of the Co-op, in his capacity as an independent director of the group, which spans supermarkets, funeral homes and pharmacies.

In a damning progress update, he warned that the company will run out of money unless it carries out “radical reform” of its board.

In the face of a massive failure of governance the need for radical reform of the group board is inescapable.

Unless the group takes urgent steps to reform its governance so that it generates sustainable economic value, it will run out of capital to support its business.

Updated at 11.59am GMT

11.28am GMT

The FTSE 100 index in London is on course for its biggest weekly fall since June, having dropped 2.8% so far this week. It is currently off 0.3%, nearly 20 points, at 6534.51. Its record weekly fall last June was triggered by the US Federal Reserve hinting it would taper economic stimulus measures later that year.

Germany’s and France’s main stock markets are also down, by 0.4% and 0.7% respectively. Gold has touched six-month highs as tensions mount in Ukraine.

IG analyst Alastair McCraig said:

Today has the distinc whiff of a ‘risk-off’ day as traders clear the decks ahead of Crimea voting this weekend. Every noise I’ve hard suggests that Crimea will vote to join Russia... and while the market is expecting that, it’s consequences of it that make it more problematic.

Updated at 11.28am GMT

11.17am GMT

Still reeling from its shock profit warning yesterday, embattled supermarket chain Morrisons suffered a theft of data from its staff payroll. The company said it learned yesterday that the data had been published on the internet and sent on a disc to a newspaper.

11.12am GMT

Tensions are rising in Ukraine, with Russia sending more troops and armour to Crimea and repeating its threat to invade other parts of Ukraine. Responding to the death of at least one protester in Ukraine’s eastern city of Donetsk, the Russian foreign ministry repeated Putin’s declaration:

Russia is aware of its responsibility for the lives of compatriots and fellow citizens in Ukraine and reserves the right to take people under its protection.

Russian stock markets have tumbled and the cost of insuring the country’s debt has soared today.

10.50am GMT

Eurozone employment slightly higher

Eurozone data show that employment across the currency bloc edged up 0.1% quarter-on-quarter between October and December – marking the first rise since the second quarter of 2011 and following flat readings in the previous two quarters.

The breakdown contains some encouraging news: Portugal has seen three consecutive quarters of growth. Spanish employment rose 0.6% quarter-on-quarter in the fourth quarter although it was still down by 1.3% year-on-year. Portuguese employment was up 0.7% on the quarter and 0.5% on the year. Greek employment edged up 0.2% on the quarter, taking the annual decline down to 2.6% from 2.9% in the third quarter.
Howard Archer, chief UK and European economist at IHS Global Insight, says this is another sign that eurozone labour markets have stabilised overall and “may be even starting to see slight improvement after extended, marked weakness”.

While this is relatively encouraging, unemployment remains worryingly high across the eurozone and it seems unlikely to come down markedly any time soon given probably gradual recovery.

Stabilising eurozone labour markets, very low inflation and improved overall confidence should provide some support to consumer spending over the coming months, although any improvement still seems most likely to be gradual given that unemployment is still high overall and earnings growth is generally weak.

Updated at 11.01am GMT

10.39am GMT

Returning to the UK’s disappointing trade figures [see 9.41am], Capital Economics economist Samuel Tombs laments that the UK economy is still not enjoying a net trade boost.

January’s trade figures continue the disappointing run of news on the UK’s export performance. Admittedly, the overall trade deficit always looked likely to widen from December’s £0.7bn figure, which was flattered by sharp fall in imports of ships and cars, which are often volatile. But January’s deficit of £2.6bn was bigger than the fourth quarter’s average of £1.8bn and 2013’s average of £2.2bn, indicating that there is still no underlying improvement in the UK’s trade position. The deterioration was driven by a sharp 4% monthly fall in exports – perhaps an early sign that the stronger pound is starting to have an adverse effect on the UK’s economic recovery.

Looking ahead, the fact that the latest industrial surveys show that export orders have grown strongly in recent months may provide some grounds for optimism. But given that these surveys have been misleadingly upbeat for several months now, we would not place too much weight on them. With demand from the UK’s main trading partners in the euro-zone unlikely to rise significantly soon, we continue to think that the UK’s economic recovery will receive little in the way of support from the external sector this year.

In other trade news....

Updated at 11.02am GMT

10.37am GMT

The global markets research team at ING says in its global monthly update, entitled “Unrest on the Eastern front”:

The escalating standoff between Ukraine and Russia over Crimea presents a new risk to the global outlook. A series of retaliatory sanctions would be unhelpful, although clearly preferable to any military conflict. Meanwhile, there are growing worries about Chinese growth and financial stability, as well as ongoing uncertainty over the strength of the US economy. Surprisingly, risk sentiment in the financial markets has held up well. There could be upsets in the near term before the underlying resilience of the major economies becomes more apparent.

The pendulum has been swinging away from Crimea remaining a regular part of Ukraine, although there still are feasible permutations in which Crimea could remain within Ukraine, albeit with greater links to Russia. The probable series of US and EU sanctions and counter-sanctions in the event of a full Crimean breakaway would weaken global growth and badly sap risk sentiment.

On a brighter note, some greater certainty is returning to the US outlook, following a better-than expected-labour report for February, lessening the chances of the US sliding back towards stagnation. It really does look as if the recent bad weather was mainly to blame for data disappointments.

The eurozone is turning the corner on growth, but this brings with it unhelpful upward pressure on the currency. With still-weak growth and plenty of risks on the horizon, this provides an unhelpful brake on the recovery. But the ECB is struggling to indicate its unease regarding EUR strength, with Draghi playing down the prospects of deflation and, in the process, giving EUR another lift. It is probably the case that there is no more easing to come from the ECB, but the sustained strength in the EUR may at least force a shift towards more cautious rhetoric.

The UK story remains very encouraging, with growth, employment and house prices rising strongly. However, there is little sign of a rebalancing yet – a concern for the medium term.

Chinese data remains distorted by Lunar New Year timing, although it does look as if there has been some slowdown in activity. But it is probably attempts to deter arbitrage between the offshore CNH and the onshore CNY, rather than overt concerns over growth or a move to a wider trading band that have prompted higher CNY fixings recently.

For a video overview of this month’s update click here.

10.17am GMT

webTitle: Thousands of Morrisons staff personal details leaked online

fields.standfirst: Police are investigating security breach as salaries, bank details and addresses are stolen
fields.body:
The personal details of thousands of Morrisons staff including salaries, bank account details and addresses have been stolen and published online.

Police are investigating the serious security breach which occurred on Thursday night and is believed to have been the result of an internal leak, with data copied onto a portable storage device and taken out of Morrisons' Bradford headquarters.

A disc of the data, which has details of staff from director level to the shop floor, was also sent anonymously to a local paper in Yorkshire, the Telegraph & Argus, by a "concerned Morrisons shopper".

The leak appeared timed to cause maximum embarrassment to Morrisons in the wake of a massive profits warning on Thursday, which sent shares diving 12%. It also came hours after the chief executive, Dalton Philips, boasted that new IT systems would help to turn around Morrisons' performance.

Morrisons said that all the staff details published were put on an unspecified location on the web for a few hours and were taken down immediately when they were discovered. It said in a statement: "We can confirm there has been no loss of customer data and no colleague will be left financially disadvantaged." It is working with police to identify the source of the theft, which "initial inquiries" suggested was not the result of an external breach of its security systems.

It said it was now "urgently reviewing our internal data security measures," and was working with UK banks and credit check service Experian to help colleagues secure their bank accounts.

Morrisons said it had contacted staff via email and its Facebook page to inform them of the leak. It also set up an email address for questions. But some staff took to social media to express their anger and complain that they had not been informed.

One post on Facebook reads: "I've been at work for nine hours and nobody has told me – good communication M!"

Another staff member wrote: "Reading about this on Facebook does not inspire confidence, we should have been notified by phone by our HR departments first thing this morning."

Another post on Facebook reads: "Ironic that Dalton Phillips was on BBC Breakfast yesterday stating he'd updated the IT systems from the 1950s. Those systems were probably too old to be hackable!"

Another post appeared to threaten action against those complaining about the leak: "This is further bad publicity for our company at a difficult time, and I'd like to ask all of my fellow colleagues to think carefully about what they say in the public domain and the effect it could have on our reputation."

The leak is the latest embarrassing issue for Morrisons, just weeks after the supermarket group's treasurer and head of tax, Paul Coyle, was arrested and questioned over alleged insider dealing relating to trading in the shares of Ocado, Morrisons' partner for its new online grocery-delivery service.

webTitle: Six budget 2014 announcements to make Britain's recovery more durable | John Muellbauer

fields.standfirst: Guest economics blogger Professor John Muellbauer outlines what he thinks George Osborne should say on Wednesday
fields.body:
The British economic recovery remains unbalanced – too driven by a credit and house price boomlet subsidised by the government's Help to Buy scheme. By raising prices of homes, especially in London and the south-east, Help to Buy defeats the purpose of extending access to housing. The six-point plan proposed here would result in a more durable recovery powered by much-needed investment in infrastructure and housing. It begins with two fundamental reforms: switching to a fiscal target that takes account not just of government debt but of assets, and setting up a national land bank, learning from international experience.

The ratio of government debt to national income matters: interest has to be paid on debt, and current national income is a rough proxy for the future national income that will generate the tax revenue to service the debt. But the current exclusive concern with debt is a big mistake: the government's asset position is just as important because assets help to generate the future income to service the debt or can be sold to pay down debt. For example, roads generate revenue directly, even without road pricing or toll roads, from taxes on petrol and licences, and indirectly from the economic activity they lubricate.

The real rate of return in Britain on such infrastructure investment – for example, upgrading the A1 in the north-east – greatly exceeds the current cost of funding. Further, much of government-owned land is obviously saleable and not hard to value. It makes no sense to include only financial assets in government net debt and exclude potentially saleable land.

The first announcement of the budget should therefore state that, in future, the government will target the growth of debt minus assets.

Increasing government debt would then not be a concern if it was matched by an increase in assets such as publicly owned productive infrastructure and land. This better target would also discourage the accounting practices of the Brown era, when expensive PFI contracts were used to fund public sector investment without recognising the underlying liabilities.

The second fundamental announcement in the budget, made possible by the first, should be the setting up of a national land bank. This acquires land cheaply and holds it for future release for housing and commercial development. In countries such as South Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong, national land banks have played major roles in urban development, supplying land for housing, generating planning gain to pay for infrastructure and in controlling real estate prices.

In Britain, with sometimes hundred-fold price differences between land with and without planning permission, a government land bank could buy land without residential or commercial planning permission but with potential for future development. In future, this would be a source of land release for housing and other development, capturing planning gain for the taxpayer. Such land purchases would initially have zero impact on correctly measured net debt, but future revaluation gains would bring down net debt, while the cashflow from sales would lower future government deficits.

This radical step, together with better incentives for local authorities to grant planning permissions, would transform the supply of housing in under-housed Britain. Currently, young people without wealthy and generous relatives have great difficulty getting onto the housing ladder. According to the census the fraction of owner occupiers among those aged 25 to 34 has declined from 58% in 2001 to 40% in 2011. The land bank proposal would allow house prices relative to income gradually to decline in coming decades, helping the "lost generation" of those born after 1979.

The next four decisions would complement these two fundamentals:

1. Substantially increase infrastructure spending.

2. Restrict Help to Buy to regions outside London and the south-east but retain Help to Build everywhere to encourage house building.

3. Announce a mansion tax in which the excess of current values above £3m is taxed at 1%.

Britain has the lowest property tax rates for the super-rich among advanced countries. The proposed tax rate would still be lower than in many other countries such as the US.

Measures 2 and 3 would take some of the heat out of housing markets in London and the south-east.

4. Take advantage of low borrowing costs in index-linked gilts to fund more than the current government deficit by issuing large amounts of index linked gilts. "Overfunding" of this kind was used in the 1980s. It would save the taxpayer money in the long run. It would also have the advantage of lifting current yields and so reducing the apparent deficits in defined-benefit pension schemes. This should boost company investment in the real economy.

These measures for balanced and sustained growth and a more equal society need a government capable of taking the long view currently lacking in Westminster.

• John Muellbauer is a professor of economics at Nuffield College and INET Oxford

webTitle: United Utilities drops after downgrade

fields.standfirst: HSBC analysts cut recommendation over uncertainties following Ofwat report
fields.body:
As the market continues its decline, one of the day's fallers is United Utilities.

Shares in the water company have dropped 6.5p to 787.5p following a downgrade from analysts at HSBC, who have moved their recommendation from neutral to underweight in the wake of a recent Ofwat report on price controls. HSBC said it was time to take profits in United, given that uncertainties remained following the watchdog's announcement. The bank said:

Ofwat has set out a scoring system that it illustrates in the report with scores of A through D where A is exceeding stakeholders' expectations through to D where substantially more evidence is required for it to understand companies' proposals and to give Ofwat "confidence that companies will deliver proposals that protect customer interests". This indicates that further dialogue is needed with companies in order to understand their business plan proposals. This includes outcomes and costs. We...conclude that more clarification is needed in a number of areas by United Utilities.
Issues for clarification (D rankings) for United Utilities include: Measurement and assurance of water outcomes; for retail – value for money and measurement and assurance; wastewater wholesale cost assessment where indicatively there is a 46% gap between Ofwat's initial financial threshold and United Utilities' business plan – a £1,131m difference that needs explaining. The uncertainties identified by Ofwat around the current period adjustments it will have to make in 2015, which we discuss above, do not provide sufficient assurance to us that a dividend cut is avoidable.

webTitle: Co-op will go bust without immediate and radical reform – Lord Myners

fields.standfirst: Damning report by former City minister and director says Co-operative Group risks being unable to continue in business
fields.body:
The Co-operative Group needs to take immediate action to reform or it runs the risk of being unable to continue in business, according to a damning report on the troubled mutual organisation.

Former City minister Lord Myners, appointed a non-executive director of the group of pharmacies, supermarkets and funeral homes after the problems exposed by the discovery of a £1.5bn capital shortfall in its bank, called for radical changes to the current organisational structure.

"Unless the group takes urgent steps to reform its governance so that it generates sustainable economic value, it will run out of capital to support its business," he said.

"The Co-operative Group suffers from acute systemic weaknesses in its governance framework that over many years have gravely damaged the organisation. These failings include a series of costly strategic misjudgments that have undermined the group's competitive position and severely eroded its capital base.

"The group board have collectively presided over losses of several billion pounds in the course of the last few years. Debt has reached levels that are no longer sustainable without the sale of treasured assets. Sale and leaseback transactions represent an expensive addiction the cost of which does not appear, even now, to be fully appreciated by the board."

At the moment the 20-strong Co-op Group board does not include the any members of the executive team, and until the appointment of Myners was made up of representatives of the 8 million members of the co-operative movement.

In his report, Myners said: "I am deeply troubled by the disdain and lack of respect for the executive team that I have witnessed from some members of the group board. There is a phrase frequently used in Co-operative Group circles that the executive should be 'on tap but not on top'.

"It is now clear to me that this is a widely held but deeply flawed representation of the reality in recent years. Elected directors have simply not been up to their task of holding the executive to account."

He said the board had spent far too much time on transactions such as Somerfield and Britannia that had been "breathtakingly value-destructive".

He also said the group's social agenda should be more aligned with its commercial objectives with "a need for a full audit of controls over money spent on social goals and given to affiliated bodies".

He proposed a new board with an independent chair, six to seven independent non-executive directors, and also a national membership council of 100 individuals, charged with making sure the group adhered to co-operative values. These proposals will be put to the 2014 annual meeting, and have to be backed by the Co-op's regional boards as well as the main board. Myners said: "Ordinary members have very little power and I recognise that, aside from the influence of corporate members from the independent societies, the future of my recommendations lies in the hands of around 100 elected individuals on the current group and regional boards, few of whom have any serious business experience and many of whom are drawing material financial benefits from their positions."

The rifts within the business were exposed on Monday when the Co-op chief executive, Euan Sutherland, walked out after just 10 months in the job, branding the organisation as "ungovernable".

His departure followed a report in the Observer which published details of his £6.6m pay deal for 2013 and 2014.

This prompted him to launch a blistering attack on "an individual or individuals" attempting to undermine him in a posting on the group's Facebook page. He also attacked the group's "professional and commercial governance" and pledged not to take £3m of controversial retention payments.

webTitle: BP closer to restoring US operations after deal with government agency

fields.standfirst: Oil firm agrees to abide by EPA monitoring arrangements for five years, allowing it to bid for drilling contracts in Gulf of Mexico
fields.body:
BP is closer to restoring its operations and reputation in the US after agreeing a deal with environmental protection authorities that it will enable the oil firm to bid for new drilling rights in the Gulf of Mexico.

The British-based group had started legal proceedings against the US environmental protection agency (EPA) which had banned BP from new contracts on the grounds that it had failed to correct problems properly since the Deepwater Horizon disaster in 2010.

BP said it had now dropped its law suit after resolving outstanding problems with the EPA but the firm will have to abide by monitoring arrangements with the agency for the next five years.

"After a lengthy negotiation, BP is pleased to have reached this resolution, which we believe to be fair and reasonable," said John Mingé, head of BP America. "Today's agreement will allow America's largest energy investor to compete again for federal contracts and leases."

BP, which claims to have invested almost $50bn (£30bn) in the US over the past five years, is still awaiting a court ruling about whether it was grossly negligent when it caused the biggest sea-borne pollution incident in American history.

The firm is confident it will be judged to have acted responsibly but a gross negligence finding would expose BP to billions of dollars worth of extra fines.

Some environmental groups have expressed opposition to the EPA deal. The Gulf Restoration Network, based in New Orleans, told the New York Times it was outrageous to allow BP to expand its offshore interests given its track record.

webTitle: Britain's trade position worsens after fall in exports

fields.standfirst: The trade in goods deficit widened to a worse than expected £9.8bn in January from £7.7bn in December
fields.body:
Britain's trade position worsened in January, as diminishing demand for British goods abroad triggered a fall in exports.

The trade in goods deficit – exports minus imports – widened to a worse than expected £9.8bn in January from £7.7bn in December, according to the Office for National Statistics.

The government's ambitions to rebalance the economy away from debt-fuelled spending and towards exports were disappointed by a 4% fall in exports in January to £24.2bn. Imports however increased by 3.4% to £34bn, as an improved economic backdrop boosted domestic demand for foreign goods.

"January's trade figures continue the disappointing run of news on the UK's export performance," said Samuel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics. He said the fall in exports might partly be explained by the recent strengthening of the pound, with a risk it was starting to have an adverse effect on the UK's economic recovery.

He added: "With demand from the UK's main trading partners in the eurozone unlikely to rise significantly soon, we continue to think that the UK's economic recovery will receive little in the way of support from the external sector this year."

Part of the weakness in the UK's trade position in January could be explained by distortions of erratic items, in particular strong imports of aircraft.

While imports from the European Union – Britain's biggest trading partner – were flat at £18bn, imports from outside the EU jumped 7.5% to £16bn in January.

Goods exports to the EU fell by 3.7% to £12.2bn, while exports to non-EU countries fell more sharply by 4.3% to £12.1bn.

The broader trade in goods and services also widened sharply to £2.6bn in January from £700m in December.

In 2012 the chancellor, George Osborne, set a target of doubling UK exports to £1 trillion by 2020. However, UK exports have remained flat since mid 2011 according to the ONS, reflecting continuing difficulties in many economies as the impact of the global financial crisis is still felt.

Brighter news on the UK economy came from the construction industry, with separate data from the ONS showing output in the sector rose by a better than expected 1.8% in January compared with a year earlier.

Rob Wood, chief UK economist at Berenberg, said that taken together the trade and construction data suggested the growth in the first quarter of 2014 would be reliant on domestic activity.

"The UK economy is heading for another strong domestically driven quarter of growth in early 2014, that will drag in imports and may worsen the sizeable trade deficit. Stimulated by booming house prices, and showing little ill effect from the weather, construction output rose 1.8% month on month in January."

webTitle: FTSE 100 on track for worst week since June but Sainsbury recovers

fields.standfirst: Leading shares continue to be hit by worries about Ukraine, Chinese slowdown and Fed
fields.body:
Following Thursday's 12% fall in Morrisons after it issued a profit warning, the supermarket has slipped another 1.2p to 204p.

Morrisons' rivals were also hit after its update, on fears of a possible price war as well as the growing importance of discounters such as Aldi and Lidl.

But J Sainsbury has recovered 9p to 313.9p as traders decided the fall was overdone. Citigroup cut its target price on Morrisons from 250p to 220p with a neutral rating, as well as reducing its target on Sainsbury from 425p to 350p, albeit still with a buy rating.

On Tesco, up 2.05p at 300.8p, Citi moved from 300p to 300p. It said:

The long-awaited profit reset in the UK grocery sector looks like it has finally begun. There has been much debate in the market since the beginning of last year as to how the big-4 grocers would respond to the increasing threat from discounters – would they continue to make only incremental investments in prices, even as market share losses accelerated, or would one of them decide to take down gross margins in a big way.
Asda and Tesco, so far, appear to have chosen the former route: Asda has committed to invest £1bn in prices over 5 years and Tesco announced a £200m price investment program last month. Yesterday's decision by Morrison to invest £300m in prices (on a much lower ex-fuel sales base compared to either Tesco or Asda) will we think hasten the adjustment in the overall UK sector profitability. We think this is a bold move by Morrisons, and believe it heralds a new era in UK food retailing. In view of Morrisons' move, we cut our profit forecasts for all the three listed UK grocers in our coverage.

Overall leading shares are on course for their worst weekly fall since June 2013, with a mixture of a possible Chinese slowdown, growing tensions in Ukraine between the government and Russia, and the prospect of the US Federal Reserve continuing to withdraw its stimulus measures all combining to unnerve investors.

The FTSE 100 is currently down 16.60 points at 6537.18, a 2.6% fall on the week so far which makes it the worst performance since the week ending 21 June last year. Sharp overnight falls on Wall Street and on Asian markets has ensured the bleak mood of recent days is continuing. Alastair McCaig, market analyst at IG, said:

Yesterday's selloffs in both the US and Asia have set the template for European traders this morning, as the distinct whiff of traders' risk-off mentality has been evident from the start. Traders are only too aware that the EU may be forced to take sanctions over Russia's recent actions.

Miners are under pressure, partly on the Ukraine worries ahead of a disputed referendum in Crimea due on Sunday and partly on recent data indicating a possible economic slowdown in China, a key consumer of commodities.

Antofagasta has fallen 8p to 827.5p while Rio Tinto is down 32p at £31.30.

webTitle: Alan Joyce won't say if Qantas will seek debt guarantee again if Senate votes no

fields.standfirst: CEO says market factors and government decisions are behind $252m loss and the need to restructure Qantas and cut 5000 jobs
fields.body:
Alan Joyce will not say if Qantas will again seek a debt guarantee if the government fails to get the repeal of part 3 of the Qantas Sale Act through the Senate.

The airline’s CEO faced a Senate rural and regional affairs and transport references committee hearing into the future of the national carrier supporting jobs on Friday.

Joyce did not take any personal responsibility for Qantas’s recent troubles, saying market factors and government decisions had largely put it in the position to post a $252m loss and make the decision to restructure and make 5000 jobs redundant.

He repeatedly said he supported the government’s decision to repeal parts of the Qantas Sales Act instead of offering the company a government backed debt guarantee.

The repeal of the Qantas Sale Act is unlikely to make it through the Senate and when asked specifically if Qantas would seek a debt guarantee again if the sale act repeal failed Joyce replied: “We’ve gone through the process now for over a number of months with both the previous government and this government about fixing the distortion [in the market] ... as we worked through that process the government gave a range of options and the government has made a decision the repeal is the appropriate way, we support the government in that and I think anything past that is hypothetical; we fully support the government in correcting this distortion.”

When asked if he took responsibility for the position of Qantas, Joyce said the increase in competitors in the Australian aviation market meant “it doesn’t matter” what he did as CEO Qantas was going to take a hit to its profitability.

“The impact on profitability has come from an environment that has resulted from oversupply of capacity internationally … I take over the last two years we’ve seen a 46% increase in capacity coming in to Australia from the international market,” he said.

Joyce cited the carbon tax as another business impact when he was asked if any government decision had led Qantas to its loss making position.

“There are a lot of decisions that go back a while that have had an impact, this market being one of the most liberal markets in the world means we’ve had 46% capacity growth since 2009,” he said.

“...we’ve had the addition of ability of 100% domestic ownership, you go to the states and it’s 25% maximum, we’ve had restrictions in Australia market that have allowed Tiger to be 100% owned by Virgin, one of the imposts on us has been the carbon tax; it’s added $106m to our bottom line and we’ve been pretty consistent on our view on the carbon tax, it does cause distortions.”

When asked why Qantas originally asked for a debt guarantee, seeing it as the best thing the Australian government could do for the company Joyce replied: “I think it’s academic now, the process has gone on.”

Joyce said the company would continue with its domestic plan of cornering the corporate and leisure markets in Australia and people who said Qantas should back away from its domestic dominance of routes did not realise what a hit that would be to the core profitability of the company.

When asked if he had the support of staff, Joyce replied: “I absolutely believe Qantas staff are aware the company needs change and the best way to secure as many jobs as possible is to make the changes we are making. They are behind the management in what we need to do and what we need to change. We have to make tough decisions It’s not easy making 5000 people redundant.”
